title: Celebrities and notable figures who died in 2025 : The famous faces we said goodbye to this year
body_text:
Celebrities and notable figures who died in 2025: The famous faces we said goodbye to this year
Oscar winners Robert Redford, Diane Keaton and Gene Hackman were among the stars the world lost in 2025, along with musical legends including Beach Boys co-founder Brian Wilson; neo-soul pioneer D'Angelo; and heavy metal legend Ozzy Osbourne.
Sunday 28 December 2025 13:27, UK
From the Pope to the Prince of Darkness, starring in his own goodbye gig just weeks before his death, the world lost many famous faces and notable figures in 2025.
We have said farewell to Hollywood icons, sporting heroes and musical legends - some at the end of long and glittering careers, others gone too soon.
Oscar winners Robert Redford, Diane Keaton and Gene Hackman were among those who died this year, along with music stars such as Brian Wilson, who co-founded The Beach Boys, and neo-soul pioneer D'Angelo.
Here, we look back at the lives and careers of those who are no longer with us.
JANUARY
David Lynch was the visionary director behind cult classic films such as Mulholland Drive and the TV series Twin Peaks.
His other notable projects included the films The Elephant Man and Blue Velvet, which, along with Mulholland Drive, earned him three Oscar nominations. In 2019, he received an honorary Academy Award for his lifetime achievements.
Steven Spielberg was among those paying tribute following his death just days before his 79th birthday, describing his fellow filmmaker as one of his heroes.
Singer and actress Marianne Faithfull was best known for her 1960s hit single As Tears Go By, and for starring roles in the films The Girl On A Motorcycle and Irina Palm. In recent years, she also provided voice work for the 2021 remake of Dune and 2023's Wild Summon.
"She was a wonderful friend, a beautiful singer and a great actress," said Mick Jagger following her death at the age of 78. The pair were in a relationship for several years in the 1960s and known as one of the most glamourous couples of the era. "She will always be remembered."
Denis Law was a footballing legend for Scotland and Manchester United. A prolific striker, he scored 237 goals in 404 appearances for the Old Trafford club, for whom he signed for a then British record transfer fee in 1962.
He is the only man to have two statues dedicated to him at Old Trafford - one on the Stretford End concourse, the other as part of the United Trinity statue beside fellow greats George Best and Sir Bobby Charlton.
Law also made 55 appearances for Scotland, scoring 30 goals - making him the country's joint top international goal-scorer, alongside Kenny Dalglish - and is the only Scottish player to have won the Ballon d'Or award.
He died at the age of 84, with United hailing him as "one of the club's greatest and most beloved players".
Read more: Law's flair and finesse would be the envy of today's game
Singer Linda Nolan rose to fame alongside her sisters Coleen, Maureen, Bernie, Denise and Anne - their group The Nolan Sisters had a run of hits in the late 1970s and '80s, including the disco classic I'm In The Mood For Dancing.
Later known as just The Nolans, they also had hits with Gotta Pull Myself Together, Attention To Me and Don't Make Waves, touring with Frank Sinatra at the height of their success.
Linda left the group in 1983, but later reformed with her sisters for several comeback performances. She also became known for musical theatre, most notably performing the role of Mrs Johnstone in Blood Brothers for three years from 2000.
As well as her TV and musical career, Linda helped to raise more than £20m for numerous charities, including Breast Cancer Now, Irish Cancer Society, Samaritans and others. She died aged 65 - after several years battling cancer - "embraced with love and comfort" with her siblings by her side, her agent said.
Drag star James Lee Williams - known as The Vivienne - first gained fame in 2015 after becoming the UK Drag Ambassador for the American series of RuPaul's Drag Race.
They later competed in the first UK series of the show in 2019, becoming a mainstream hit initially thanks to their impression of Donald Trump, before going on to win the series after lip-syncing in the final to the Wham! hit, I'm Your Man.
Williams also performed as the Wicked Witch of the West in a UK and Ireland tour of The Wizard Of Oz musical, reprising the role in the West End last year, and came third in the 2023 series of Dancing On Ice.
They died aged 32 after taking ketamine. Family members said they wanted to share this publicly to raise awareness about the dangers of the drug "and what it can do to your body". In a tribute, the family said they were "so proud of the wonderful things" Williams had achieved.
Read more: From RuPaul's Drag Race to mainstream star
Other deaths in January 2025 included:
The Osmonds singer Wayne Osmond
Soul singer Sam Moore, of Sam & Dave
British actress Dame Joan Plowright
White Snake and Thin Lizzy guitarist John Sykes
Peter, Paul and Mary singer-songwriter Peter Yarrow
French far-right politician Jean-Marie Le Pen
Actor and comedian Tony Slattery
Former Hollyoaks and reality star Paul Danan
Director Claire van Kampen
Flog It! antiques expert Michael Baggott
Filmmaker Jeff Baena
FEBRUARY
A former marine, Gene Hackman's work on screen began with an uncredited TV role in 1961. He went on to become a Hollywood legend - despite his disdain for all things showbiz - playing villains, heroes and antiheroes in more than 80 films, as well as small screen roles and performances on Broadway.
To many, he will forever be known as Superman villain Lex Luthor, but his other memorable roles included that of New York City detective Jimmy "Popeye" Doyle in The French Connection, and surveillance expert Harry Caul in Francis Ford Coppola's The Conversation.
Hackman also starred in The Poseidon Adventure, A Bridge Too Far, Under Fire, Mississippi Burning, Crimson Tide, Get Shorty, The Royal Tenenbaums and Runaway Jury. He was decorated with multiple Oscars, BAFTAs and Golden Globes, but stepped away from acting in 2004 to pursue novel writing, which he said better suited his solitary nature.
He died aged 95 along with his wife, Betsy Arakawa, 63, with the couple's bodies found at their home in New Mexico.
Read more: The reluctant celebrity who could play any role
Grammy-winning singer Roberta Flack was best known for her hits Killing Me Softly With His Song, later covered by The Fugees, and The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face.
Discovered in the late 1960s by jazz musician Les McCann, she went on to become one of the top recording artists of the 1970s - becoming an almost overnight success after Clint Eastwood chose The First Time to soundtrack the explicit love scenes of his 1971 movie, Play Misty For Me.
A shining light in the social and civil rights movement of the time, Flack was friends with Reverend Jesse Jackson, and also sang at the funeral of Jackie Robinson, Major League Baseball's first black player.
She died aged 88, three years after announcing she was suffering from motor neurone disease and could no longer sing.
Actress Michelle Trachtenberg was best known for her role as Dawn Summers in Buffy, the younger sister of the titular character played by Sarah Michelle Gellar between 2000 and 2003.
Between 2008 and 2012, she also played Georgina Sparks in Gossip Girl - the malevolent rival of Blake Lively's Serena van der Woodsen and Leighton Meester's Blair Waldorf.
Her first big break into Hollywood came in 1996, starring in the big screen adaptation of Harriet the Spy, and she also starred in 17 Again, Eurotrip and Ice Princess. Her most recent film appearance came last year, when she played the role of Michelle Cody White in Spyral.
She died aged 39 as a result of complications from diabetes, a medical examiner said. Gellar paid tribute to her former co-star, saying "I will always love you".
Other deaths in February 2025 included:
Carry On actor Julian Holloway
Music producer and Murder Inc label founder Irv Gotti
Going For Gold and Game For A Laugh presenter Henry Kelly
The Jam drummer Rick Buckler
Taiwanese actress Barbie Hsu
New York Dolls singer David Johansen
Nigel McCrery, creator of Silent Witness and New Tricks
Man About The House and George And Mildred star Brian Murphy
South Korean actress Kim Sae-ron
Eggheads quizzer Chris Hughes
MARCH
George Foreman was a US heavyweight boxing legend, a two-time champion who fought Muhammad Ali in one of the sport's most legendary fights, the "Rumble in the Jungle".
He became the oldest champion in history aged 45 in 1994, two decades after the famous fight.
Outside the ring, his transformation from a brooding boxer to a jovial, TV-friendly personality helped make him a fortune with his range of grills in the 1990s.
He died aged 76, surrounded by loved ones, after an "extraordinary life", his family said.
Read more: How boxing legend became a cultural icon
Angie Stone was a Grammy-nominated US hip-hop and neo-soul pioneer, whose group The Sequence was one of the first all-female groups to record a rap song.
The group's most popular song, 1979's Funk You Up, peaked at 15 on Billboard's Hot Soul Singles.
As a solo artist, she was best known for the 2002 hit Wish I Didn't Miss You, and she also had a number of successful collaborations with artists such as Guru, Omar, Macy Gray, Moby, Prince and Blue - including on the British band's 2003 top 11 chart hit Signed, Sealed, Delivered, I'm Yours.
Stone also appeared in films including The Hot Chick, The Fighting Temptations, and Ride Along, and trod the boards on Broadway as Big Mama Morton in the musical Chicago.
She died in a car crash in Alabama, aged 63.
Renowned Scottish painter Jack Vettriano was the artist behind The Singing Butler, the world famous image of an elegant couple dancing on a storm-swept beach, accompanied by their butler and maid.
In 2004, the painting sold at auction for £744,800 - a record at the time for any Scottish painting and for any painting ever sold in Scotland.
Among those to have acquired Vettriano paintings are Hollywood legend Jack Nicholson, former Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson, songwriter Sir Tim Rice, and the late Harry Potter actor Robbie Coltrane.
Vettriano died at his apartment in Nice, aged 73. "His evocative and timeless works will continue to captivate and inspire future generations," his publicist said as he paid tribute.
Other deaths in March 2025 included:
The Damned founding guitarist Brian James
Jazz musician Roy Ayers
Badfinger guitarist Joey Molland
Dr Kildare and Shogun actor Richard Chamberlain
Dolly Parton's husband Carl Dean
Spitting Image producer Bill Dare
APRIL
Pope Francis was elected in 2013 after the resignation of his predecessor, Benedict XVI.
Born in 1936, he was the first pope from South America and his papacy was marked by his championing of those escaping war and hunger, as well as those in poverty, earning him the moniker the "People's Pope".
In 2016, he famously washed the feet of refugees from different religions at an asylum centre outside Rome, in a "gesture of humility and service".
He also made his views known on a wide range of issues, from climate change to wealth inequality and the role of women in the Catholic Church, and his acceptance of the LGBTQ community was unprecedented.
In his final years, his papacy was marked by several hospital visits and concerns about his health. He died peacefully at the age of 88, just a day after greeting crowds on Easter Sunday.
Read more: Pope Francis: A life in pictures
Val Kilmer was a Hollywood star known for several huge performances - including Batman in the 1995 film Batman Forever, The Saint in 1997, and portraying rock singer Jim Morrison in the 1991 movie The Doors.
But he is probably best remembered as Iceman, rival to Tom Cruise's Maverick in the 1986 blockbuster Top Gun.
Kilmer later admitted he didn't want the role at first - but said he begged to be in the long-awaited sequel, released in 2022, which turned out to be his last ever big screen performance.
He died aged 65 after suffering from pneumonia, his daughter said, with Cruise leading tributes to his "dear friend".
Blondie drummer Clem Burke (above left) joined the band, fronted by Debbie Harry, a year after their formation in 1975.
He played on all their studio albums, from their self-titled debut to the 1978 classic Parallel Lines and most recently, 2017's Pollinator. He will also appear on an upcoming record now due for release next year, which the band worked on before his death.
During his career, Burke also featured on Iggy Pop's 1982 album Zombie Birdhouse and performed with Bob Dylan, The Ramones, The Who guitarist Pete Townshend and Joan Jett. Harry, and Blondie guitarist Chris Stein paid tribute to "the heartbeat of Blondie" following his death at the age of 70, after being diagnosed with cancer.
Other deaths in April 2025 included:
Upstairs, Downstairs actress Jean Marsh
RuPaul's Drag Race star Jiggly Caliente
The Alarm frontman Mike Peters
Eurovision star Clodagh Rodgers
Dennis The Menace star Jay North
Designer David Sassoon
MAY
Alan Yentob was a former BBC executive and presenter who joined the broadcaster as a trainee in 1968.
He went on to hold several senior positions in the corporation including controller of BBC One and BBC Two, director of television, and head of music and art. He was also the director of BBC drama, entertainment, and children's TV, launching CBBC and CBeebies - and his drama commissions included Pride And Prejudice and Middlemarch.
The TV executive was made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) by the King in 2024, for services to the arts and media. Following his death at the age of 78, his family paid tribute to "a profoundly moral man" who left "in his wake a trail of love a mile wide".
In Cheers, George Wendt played an affable, beer-loving regular at the Boston bar "where everybody knows your name" - a fact emphasised by every entrance his character made, when fellow patrons would shout "Norm!" to greet him.
He appeared as Norm in all 273 episodes of the show, watched by millions throughout the 1980s and early 1990s, and starred alongside the likes of Ted Danson, Shelley Long, Kelsey Grammer, Kirstie Alley and Woody Harrelson.
The series won 28 Emmy awards over the years, with 117 nominations - including six consecutive nods for Wendt in the best supporting actor category. He was also a prominent presence on Broadway, appearing on stage in Art, Hairspray and Elf.
His family paid tribute to "a well-loved friend and confidant to all of those lucky enough to have known him" following his death at 76.
Other stars and notable figures who died in May 2025 include:
Music agent Dave Shapiro and drummer Daniel Williams
Kool & The Gang's Michael Sumler
M.A.S.H star Loretta Swit
Songwriter Jill Sobule
Race Across The World contestant Sam Gardiner
JUNE
Brian Wilson co-founded The Beach Boys in the early 1960s with his brothers, Dennis and Carl, their cousin Mike Love and friend Al Jardine. He was their visionary leader and songwriter, penning hits including Surfin' USA, Good Vibrations, Wouldn't It Be Nice, and God Only Knows.
Their 1966 album Pet Sounds was voted number two in a 2003 Rolling Stone list of the best 500 albums ever - losing out only to The Beatles' Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band. Sir Paul McCartney cited Pet Sounds as a direct inspiration for the Beatles, naming God Only Knows as one of his favourite songs, saying it often brought him to tears.
Sir Elton John, Bruce Springsteen, The Ramones and Weezer are among the many other artists who have said they were inspired by the group.
Wilson had suffered ill health in the years before his death at 82. "We realise that we are sharing our grief with the world," his family said as they paid tribute.
As frontman for Sly And The Family Stone, Sly Stone fused soul, rock, psychedelia and gospel to take the funk sound that defined an era in the 1960s into new territory, second only to James Brown as an early founder.
Several of the band's seminal tracks became known to a wider audience when they were subsequently sampled by hip hop artists, including Everyday People by Arrested Development, and Sing A Simple Song by several acts including Public Enemy, De La Soul, and Dr Dre and Snoop Dogg.
The band was inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 1993 and Stone was celebrated in an all-star tribute at the Grammy Awards in 2006. He published a memoir last year and recently completed a screenplay based on his life story just before his death at 82.
Frederick Forsyth was an RAF pilot, foreign affairs journalist, MI6 agent and bestselling thriller writer.
As a journalist he covered international stories and the attempted assassination of French general Charles de Gaulle, which provided the inspiration for his most famous novel, The Day Of The Jackal. His other thrillers included The Odessa File, The Dogs Of War and The Fourth Protocol.
In 2000, he became the first high-profile British writer to agree to publish a book exclusively on the internet.
His involvement with MI6 was revealed in his 2015 memoir The Outsider: My Life In Intrigue. In total, he wrote more than 25 books, many of which were made into films, selling more than 75 million copies.
"We mourn the passing of one of the world's greatest thriller writers," said his agent following his death at 86.
Kim Woodburn was the self-styled "Queen of Clean". A former cleaner, she found fame presenting the hit TV show How Clean Is Your House? alongside Aggie MacKenzie in the 2000s, and later became a runner-up on Celebrity Big Brother in 2017.
She also appeared on E4's Celebrity Cooking School, The Oprah Winfrey Show, Big Brother's Bit On The Side, Celebrity Come Dine With Me and A Place In The Sun, as well as regularly contributing to ITV's This Morning and Loose Women.
Known for her trademark tight, plaited bun, she was largely blind in her right eye and had poor sight in her left eye, and earlier this year had told her followers she was undergoing emergency eye surgery.
She died aged 83, with her manager paying tribute to "an incredibly kind, caring, charismatic and strong person".
Other deaths in June 2025 included:
King Of The Hill and Parks And Recreation actor Jonathan Joss
Mott The Hoople and Bad Company drummer Mike Ralphs
Character actor and Broadway star Harris Yulin
JULY
Self-styled Prince of Darkness Ozzy Osbourne pioneered heavy metal as Black Sabbath's lead singer with hits like Paranoid and War Pigs. He later had huge success as a solo artist.
He was known for his hellraising antics during his rock star heyday - most infamously, the tale of how he bit the head off a bat while on stage.
In the 2000s, he found a new generation of fans as one of MTV's first reality stars, thanks to The Osbournes, the show that shared his chaotic homelife with the world, where he appeared alongside wife Sharon and two of his children, Kelly and Jack.
Ill health in recent years led to Sharon organising his "final bow" gig at Villa Park in July 2025, a show which saw the star reunite with Black Sabbath after performances by acts including Guns 'N' Roses and Metallica.
He died less than three weeks later, with musicians from Sir Elton John to Ronnie Wood paying tribute - and Black Sabbath sharing the immortal words: "Ozzy Forever!"
Read more: The wild life of the Prince of Darkness
Footballer Diogo Jota began his career in his native Portugal and then played at Atletico Madrid in Spain before moving to England. After joining Liverpool from Wolverhampton Wanderers in 2020, he went on to score a total of 47 goals in 123 matches - including six goals during Liverpool's 2024/25 Premier League-winning season.
He also played 49 times for the Portugal national side, scoring 14 times.
A father of three, he married his long-term girlfriend, Rute Cardoso, in June. Less than two weeks later, he was killed in a car crash in Spain, aged just 28. His brother, Andre Silva, 25, who played for Portuguese club Penafiel, also died.
Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk, manager Arne Slot, Portugal captain Cristiano Ronaldo were among the many stars of football who paid tribute. Liverpool described his death as an "unimaginable loss".
Read more: The joy of final weeks before tragic death
Hulk Hogan, real name Terry Bollea, was perhaps the most iconic star in WWE's five-decade history - known for his distinctive blonde moustache and colourful headbands. He was credited with helping to bring a new audience to professional wrestling thanks to his charisma and theatrics in the ring.
He claimed his first WWE world championship by defeating the Iron Sheik in 1984 and was the main draw for the first-ever WrestleMania event in 1985.
Hogan won six world championships in total and was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame in 2005 by Sylvester Stallone. He went on to become a vocal supporter of Donald Trump during last year's presidential election campaign.
WWE paid tribute to "one of pop culture's most recognisable figures" after his death at 71, saying he had helped the organisation "achieve global recognition".
Michael Madsen appeared in dozens of films during a career in entertainment that spanned more than 40 years, with screen credits including Thelma And Louise, Free Willy, Donnie Brasco and Sin City.
But he was best known for his collaborations with filmmaker Quentin Tarantino, who cast him as Mr Blonde in the 1992 film Reservoir Dogs. The role gave him perhaps his most memorable moment on screen - the torture of a captured police officer, while dancing to Stealers Wheel's Stuck In The Middle With You. Tarantino went on to cast him in Kill Bill: Vol 2, The Hateful Eight and Once Upon A Time In Hollywood.
"I could have been a bricklayer. I could have been an architect. I could have been a garbage man. I could have been nothing. But I got lucky. I got lucky as an actor," Madsen said as his handprints were immortalised in Hollywood in 2020.
"My brother Michael has left the stage," his sister, Oscar-nominated actress Virginia Madsen, said in a statement following his death at 67.
Former Conservative cabinet minister Norman Tebbit was one of Margaret Thatcher's staunchest political allies and the survivor of an IRA bombing in 1984.
He was a leading political voice throughout the turbulent 1980s, entering the cabinet as employment secretary and leaving six years later having been Conservative Party chairman.
As a working-class boy from north London - and not a "knight from the shires", he was proud of his ability to retain a "line of communication" with "those people" who came from similarly humble backgrounds.
Before politics he had a career as a pilot, first for the RAF and then for the BOAC airline.
He was one of Mrs Thatcher's more plain speaking ministers - Labour's Michael Foot called him a "semi house-trained pole cat" and Spitting Image satirists famously him kitted out in black leather and bovver boots.
Among his most famous moments were the comments he made in the aftermath of riots of 1981. It was an era of high unemployment and the then employment secretary evoked the memory of his father who lost his job in the 1930s. "He didn't riot," he said. "He got on his bike and looked for work."
His political career was cut short by the IRA bombing of the Grand Hotel in Brighton during the 1984 Conservative Party conference. He was badly injured, spent three months in hospital and then stepped down from the government to care for his wife Margaret who was paralysed in the same attack and spent the rest of her life in a wheelchair.
Tory leader Kemi Badenoch called him an "icon" in British politics and said he was "one of the leading exponents of the philosophy we now know as Thatcherism", following his death at 94.
Read more: A bruiser until the very end
Other deaths in July 2025 included:
Grammy-winning jazz singer and actress Cleo Laine
Grammy-winning jazz musician Chuck Mangione
Double Olympic champion Laura Dahlmeier
The Cosby Show star Malcolm-Jamal Warner
Extreme athlete Felix Baumgartner
Pretty Little Baby and Stupid Cupid singer Connie Francis
Nip/Tuck and Fantastic Four star Julian McMahon
AUGUST
Jim Lovell was one of NASA's most-travelled astronauts in the agency's first decade, flying four times in the 1960s - on Gemini 7, Gemini 8, Apollo 8 and Apollo 13. As commander of the famous Apollo 13 mission, he helped turn failure into triumph after managing to get back to Earth safely following an oxygen tank explosion.
He had been set to become the fifth man to walk on the moon but the flight was thrown into jeopardy by the sudden blast - which occurred when the spacecraft was 200,000 miles away from Earth. Lovell and the two other astronauts on board - Fred Haise and Jack Swigert - barely survived and spent four cold days in the cramped lunar module while working with engineers and controllers on the ground to devise a rescue plan.
"Lovell's life and work inspired millions," NASA said after his death at 97. "His courage under pressure helped forge our path to the moon and beyond - a journey that continues today."
British actor Terence Stamp was a star of 1960s cinema who went on to play General Zod in Superman and Superman II, and also starred in hits such as Theorem, A Season in Hell, and The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert.
The Oscar-nominated star, who was born in London's East End, formed one of Britain's most glamorous couples with Julie Christie, with whom he appeared in Far From The Madding Crowd in 1967.
He received various accolades throughout his career, including a Golden Globe in 1962 for most promising newcomer for Billy Budd, and a Cannes Film Festival best actor award in 1965 for The Collector.
He died aged 87, with his family saying: "He leaves behind an extraordinary body of work, both as an actor and as a writer that will continue to touch and inspire people for years to come."
Jerry Adler (pictured above right with former co-star Vincent Pastore) was best known for playing Herman "Hesh" Rabkin, a confidant to mobster Tony Soprano, in The Sopranos TV series.
Earlier in his life, he spent years in theatre, working behind the scenes on some of Broadway's biggest shows.
He worked as stage manager for the original 1956 production of My Fair Lady, featuring Julie Andrews and Rex Harrison, and later directed the revival in 1976 - after working on shows such as Annie, Marlene Dietrich and "We Interrupt This Program..." as a production supervisor and director.
His first acting credit came in 1991, when he appeared on an episode of Brooklyn Bridge, and he went on to appear on popular television series such as Quantum Leap and Law & Order.
"You know him from one of his iconic roles [and] from many of his guest appearances," his friend Frank J Reilly wrote on X as he confirmed his death. "Not bad for a guy who didn't start acting until he was 65."
Other deaths in August 2025 included:
Former Mastodon guitarist Brett Hinds
Country singer and producer Jeannie Seely
Hollywood stuntman Ronnie Rondell Jr
General Hospital actor Tristan Rogers
Pianist and composer Eddie Palmieri
What's Happening!! actress Danielle Spencer
Actress Loni Anderson
SEPTEMBER
During his 15-year professional career between 1997 and 2012, British fighter Ricky "The Hitman" Hatton won multiple welterweight and light-welterweight world titles.
In his prime, he secured victories over the likes of Kostya Tszyu and Jose Luis Castillo, before going on to suffer brutal knockout losses to Floyd Mayweather Jr in 2007 and Manny Pacquiao in 2009. He last fought professionally in November 2012, suffering a knockout loss to Ukraine's Vyacheslav Senchenko - but announced he was coming out of retirement for a bout in Dubai just a few months before his death.
Boxers including Amir Khan, Tyson Fury, Chris Eubank Jr and Barry McGuigan, footballers Michael Owen and Wayne Rooney, and music star Liam Gallagher all paid tribute to the 46-year-old. Sky News sport correspondent Rob Harris described him as "one of the great personalities of British boxing".
Read more: Everybody wanted a piece of Ricky Hatton
Hollywood actor and Oscar-winning director Robert Redford was known for films including Butch Cassidy And The Sundance Kid, All The President's Men and The Sting - and also founded the Sundance Film Festival, the largest independent film festival in the US.
In the 1990s and 2000s, his film credits included Indecent Proposal, The Last Castle and Spy Game, and he also worked actively as a filmmaker - helming movies including A River Runs Through It and The Legend Of Bagger Vance. In 1998, he both starred in and directed The Horse Whisperer.
His legacy lives on in the Sundance Film Festival, which grew into a cornerstone of the film industry and provided a launch pad for filmmakers including Quentin Tarantino, Paul Thomas Anderson, Steven Soderbergh, Gina Prince-Bythewood and Darren Aronofsky. In 2016, Barack Obama awarded him the Presidential Medal of Freedom - considered the US government's highest civilian honour - saying at the time that Americans "admire Bob not just for his remarkable acting, but for having figured out what to do next".
Co-stars Meryl Streep and Jane Fonda were among those paying tribute following his death at 89. "One of the lions has passed," said Streep, who starred opposite Redford in Out Of Africa and Lions For Lambs. "Bob made a real difference in all good ways," said Fonda.
Read more: Robert Redford's career in pictures
Born in the small northern Italian town of Piacenza in July 1934, Georgio Armani originally wanted to be a doctor but changed his mind after a part-time job as a window dresser at a Milan store gave him an insight into the world of fashion for the first time.
As one of the most influential designers of the 20th century, he is often credited with spearheading red carpet fashion and was planning a major event shortly before he died, to mark 50 years of his brand, during Milan Fashion Week.
Armani put Italian ready-to-wear style on the map in the late 1970s with his signature "Armani suit", before adapting its classic style for women with the launch of the female power suit in the 1980s.
He worked on more than 200 films, most notably earlier in his career on American Gigolo with Richard Gere in 1980, and dressed Hollywood A-listers and music stars, including George Clooney, Cate Blanchett and Lady Gaga - and famously Julia Roberts in an oversized men's suit for the Golden Globes in 1990.
"Il Signor Armani, as he was always respectfully and admiringly called by employees and collaborators, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his loved ones" at 91, his fashion house said as they announced his death.
Read more: The best looks created by Armani
The assasination of conservative activist Charlie Kirk shocked the world in September.
The 31-year-old, who founded Turning Point USA and toured American university campuses, debating students about current affairs, was fatally shot on 10 September while speaking at an event at Utah Valley University.
In October, he was posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the USA's highest civilian honour, by Donald Trump.
A 22-year-old man has been charged with murder and prosecutors have said they will seek the death penalty.
Read more: Tearful message is one America needs to hear
Journalist John Stapleton was a veteran broadcaster who appeared on well known programmes such as Watchdog, Nationwide, Newsnight, Good Morning Britain, Panorama, and GMTV's News Hour, and was also among the first presenters on Sky News.
Following career beginnings at local papers in Greater Manchester, he covered many of the biggest news events over 50 years, interviewing prime ministers and appearing in shows with millions of viewers. For Sky News, he appeared on a programme called Newsline in 1989 - with Margaret Thatcher among those facing his questions during the channel's launch year.
One of his highlights was being named Royal Television Society presenter of the year in 2004 for his work on the Iraq War, and a series of interviews that included Sir Tony Blair.
In recent years, he had spoken about being diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. He died aged 79, with former colleagues including Sky News' Mark Austin paying tribute to "a good man and top presenter who could turn his hand to anything".
Cricket umpire Dickie Bird unusually came to be one of the best known figures in the sport, famous for his amusing interactions with players and fans alike.
In an umpiring career spanning nearly 30 years, he stood in 66 Test matches and 69 one-day internationals, including three World Cup finals. It came after his time playing the sport for Yorkshire and then Leicestershire ended when he retired aged 31, due to a persistent knee injury.
His 1997 autobiography sold more than a million copies, becoming the nation's biggest-selling sports book ever at the time, and he entertained the public for years as a TV personality and travelling raconteur. In a favoured story, he claimed his one-man show drew a bigger audience in Leeds than superstar singer Shirley Bassey.
He was awarded an MBE in 1986 and an OBE in 2012, in recognition of his outstanding contribution to the sport. "Dickie Bird enjoyed an illustrious career as an international umpire, writing his name into history as the most famous and popular official in the game's history," Yorkshire County Cricket Club said in tribute following his death at 92.
Other deaths in September 2025 included:
Dances With Wolves and Green Mile star Graham Greene
Katharine, Duchess of Kent
Supertramp founder Rick Davies
Former Arsenal academy player Billy Vigar
Country singer Brett James
Pink Panther star Claudia Cardinale
OCTOBER
Diane Keaton was an Oscar, BAFTA and Golden Globe winner who was also nominated for two Emmys and a Tony.
She won her Academy Award for best actress for the Woody Allen film Annie Hall, said to be loosely based on her life, and appeared in several other Allen projects, including Manhattan. She also starred in all three Godfather movies, playing Kay, the wife and then ex-wife of Marlon Brando's son Michael Corleone, played by Al Pacino.
Keaton also frequently worked with filmmaker Nancy Meyers, with collaborations include 1987's Baby Boom, 1991's Father Of The Bride and its 1995 sequel, as well as 2003's Something's Gotta Give. In 1996, she starred opposite Goldie Hawn and Bette Midler in The First Wives Club, about three women whose husbands leave them for younger women, and more recently she collaborated with Jane Fonda, Mary Steenburgen and Candice Bergen on the Book Club films.
Her First Wives co-stars led tributes following her death at 79, with Midler describing her as "hilarious, a complete original", and Hawn saying she had left "a trail of fairy dust, filled with particles of light and memories beyond imagination".
After starting out as a songwriter working with artists such as Lauryn Hill and The Roots, trailblazing neo-soul singer D'Angelo rose to prominence in the 1990s with his first album, Brown Sugar. The track Lady reached number 10 in March 1996 and remained on Billboard's Hot 100 chart for 20 weeks.
After a break from recording of almost five years, he returned with Voodoo, released in 2000, which topped the Billboard chart and featured the hit Untitled (How Does It Feel) - the song that became famous for its single-shot video, in which he appeared to be performing naked.
His third and final studio album, Black Messiah, came after an even longer break, in 2014.
He won four Grammys throughout his career and inspired artists from Beyonce to Tyler The Creator. He died aged 51, leaving behind a "legacy of extraordinarily moving music" following a "prolonged and courageous battle with cancer," his family said in a statement.
Dame Jilly Cooper was the best-selling author renowned for her raunchy, so-called "bonkbuster" novels, including Rivals and Riders - portraying the scandals and sex lives of those in wealthy country social circles.
She was propelled to commercial success in the 1980s, selling 11 million copies of her books during a career of more than 50 years. In 2024, Rivals was adapted into a successful TV series, which she worked on as an executive producer.
The Queen, a friend, led tributes following Dame Jilly's death at the age of 88, describing her as "a legend in [her] own lifetime" who "created a whole new genre of literature" and made it her own. Ending her tribute with a wish for her "witty and compassionate" friend, Camilla said: "And may her hereafter be filled with impossibly handsome men and devoted dogs."

Former presidents Barack Obama, Bill Clinton and Joe Biden were among many notable figures from around the world paying tribute following the death of British conservationist and primatologist Dame Jane Goodall at 91.
Known for her pioneering studies of chimpanzees, Dame Jane began her research at 26, observing the animals in east Africa and revealing their capability to engage in complex social behaviours.
She gave chimps names instead of numbers, observed their distinct personalities and their use of tools - previously thought to be exclusive to humans.
Her work laid a path for other female primatologists and conservationists, including Dian Fossey (portrayed by Sigourney Weaver in the Hollywood movie Gorillas In The Mist), and she appeared in numerous National Geographic programmes, wrote more than 30 books, and also in The Simpsons.
Later in her career, Dame Jane shifted more towards climate advocacy after seeing habitats diminishing, and spoke to Sky News about the issue in June.
She was made a dame in 2003 and awarded the prestigious US Presidential Medal of Freedom earlier this year.
Prunella Scales had a seven-decade acting career which saw her in multiple roles from the 1950s, including in 1960s sitcom Marriage Lines, before her most famous performance - playing Sybil, the long-suffering wife of John Cleese's Basil Fawlty, in Fawlty Towers.
The comedy, set in a hotel in the seaside resort of Torquay, ran for just two series in the 1970s, but remains one of the UK's best loved sitcoms and was developed into a theatre production that moved to London's West End in 2024.
Cleese led the tributes following her death at 93, saying: "Scene after scene she was absolutely perfect." The star, who was living with dementia, was watching the sitcom the day before she died, her sons Samuel and Joseph West said.
Dame Patricia Routledge (pictured with Clive Swift, who played her on-screen husband) played the notoriously snobbish Hyacinth Bucket in the BBC sitcom Keeping Up Appearances between 1990 and 1995.
The comedy attracted as many as 13 million viewers at its peak and the actress earned two BAFTA nominations for the role, in 1992 and 1993. Another of her notable 90s TV appearances came when she played a pensioner-turned-detective in the BBC crime series, Hetty Wainthropp Investigates.
Dame Patricia also had a prolific career in the theatre, winning an Olivier Award for her role as the Old Lady in acclaimed composer Leonard Bernstein's operetta Candide in 1988, and a Tony Award for her part as Alice Challice in Darling Of The Day in 1968.
The actress was honoured at Buckingham Palace in 2017, being made a Dame Commander of the British Empire for her services to the theatre and charity.
"Even at 96 years old, Dame Patricia's passion for her work and for connecting with live audiences never waned, just as new generations of audiences have continued to find her through her beloved television roles," her agent said following her death.

NOVEMBER
King Charles led the tributes following the death of playwright Tom Stoppard, describing him as "one of our greatest writers", and a "dear friend who wore his genius lightly".
Sir Tom's entertainment career spanned more than six decades, during which he won a host of Tony and Olivier awards, as well as the Golden Globe and Academy Award with Marc Norman for their 1998 screenplay Shakespeare In Love - starring fellow Oscar-winner Gwyneth Paltrow.
His award-winning plays included Rosencrantz And Guildenstern Are Dead, The Real Thing and Travesties, and he also wrote prolifically for TV, radio and film - including adapting Leo Tolstoy's novel Anna Karenina for the 2012 film starring Keira Knightley and Jude Law, and the TV series Parade's End with Benedict Cumberbatch and Rebecca Hall.
He received countless accolades and honours during his career, including being knighted by the late Queen for his services to literature in 1997.
He died at the age of 88, with his agents saying he would be remembered for the "brilliance and humanity" of his works, and "profound love of the English language".
Bassist Gary "Mani" Mounfield joined The Stone Roses in 1987, forming part of the band's classic line-up alongside singer Ian Brown, guitarist John Squire and drummer Alan "Reni" Wren.
They were a mainstay of the "Madchester" scene of bands, also including Happy Mondays, Inspiral Carpets and The Charlatans, known for blending indie with acid house, psychedelia and pop.
Their eponymous debut album, released in 1989, featured hits such as I Wanna Be Adored and I Am The Resurrection - and was later named the second greatest album of all time in a "Music of the Millennium" poll - losing out only to The Beatles' Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band.
Mani joined Primal Scream after The Stone Roses split in 1996, and played with them until the Roses reunited in 2011. His death at 63 came two years after that of his wife, Imelda Mounfield, who was diagnosed with bowel cancer in November 2020. Stone Roses frontman Ian Brown, Oasis star Liam Gallagher and Happy Mondays' Shaun Ryder all paid tribute, with Gallagher describing Mani as his "hero".
Diane Ladd (pictured left above with daughter Laura Dern), 89, was a triple Oscar nominee for her supporting roles in Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore, Wild At Heart and Rambling Rose. She also starred in the 1973 film White Lightning and HBO's Enlightened in 2011, with her daughter.
They often played mother and daughter together - and for Rambling Rose, in 1991, they became the first and only mother and daughter duo to receive Oscar nominations for the same film in the same year. In 2023 they released a joint memoir, titled Honey, Baby, Mine: A Mother and Daughter Talk Life, Death, Love.
Dern, known for Jurassic Park and Marriage Story, said of her mother in 2019: "She is just the greatest actress, ever. You don't even use the word brave because she just shows up like that in life. She doesn't care what anybody thinks."
Republican Dick Cheney (left above) was one of the most polarising vice presidents in US history, under George W Bush from 2001 to 2009, and one of the main foreign policy hawks ahead of the invasion of Iraq in 2003.
He also led US policy after the 9/11 attacks, when America conducted the War on Terror, and shaped the administration's more assertive international approach.
In later life, he became a target of Donald Trump, especially after his daughter, Liz Cheney, became the leading Republican critic and examiner of Mr Trump's actions surrounding the January 2021 insurrection at the US Capitol. In 2024, he said he was voting for Kamala Harris, the Democratic candidate, to be president.
Before his death at 84 he had survived five heart attacks, and declared in 2013 that he woke up each morning "with a smile on my face, thankful for the gift of another day".

Jimmy Cliff was a musical artist who helped bring reggae to an international audience, known for hits including You Can Get It If You Really Want, his covers of Hakuna Matata and I Can See Clearly Now, and the title track from the seminal film, The Harder They Come.
Inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2010, he was a two-time Grammy-winning artist and awarded the Jamaican Order of Merit - the country's highest honour in the arts and sciences - in 2003.
Among his other famous songs was 1969's Vietnam, reportedly described by Bob Dylan as "the best protest song" he had ever heard. His last studio album, Refugees, was released in 2022, and the singer said he wrote the title track "due to emotional feelings towards freedom taken away from human beings".
His wife, Latifa Chambers, led tributes following his death at 81, with a message to fans - "please know that your support was his strength throughout his whole career. He really appreciated each and every fan for their love".
Indian film star and Bollywood icon Dharmendra was one of the nation's most popular actors, a defining presence in Indian cinema in the 1970s and 1980s.
Known as the country's He-Man, he was often cast as a larger-than-life hero who was upright, patriotic and fearless, and was compared to Hollywood contemporaries such as James Dean and Paul Newman, according to the Hindustan Times.
He appeared in Sholay - a 1975 spin on the spaghetti western, regarded as one of India's greatest films - and will also be remembered for the 1975 romantic comedy Chupke Chupke, and the 1971 action drama Mera Gaon Mera Desh. His final film will be the war biopic Ikkis, which is yet to be released.
He died just days before his 90th birthday.

DECEMBER
Sophie Kinsella was the author of the famous Shopaholic series of novels - the first two of which were adapted into the 2009 film Confessions Of A Shopaholic, starring Isla Fisher.
Other books by the London-born author include The Burnout, Can You Keep A Secret?, The Undomestic Goddess, and her most recent, What Does it Feel Like?, in October 2024. She sold more than 45 million copies of her works in more than 60 countries.
The writer, whose real name was Madeleine Sophie Wickham, revealed last year she had been diagnosed with an aggressive form of brain cancer in 2022.
She died at 55, with fellow author Jojo Moyes, who was friends with her for decades, describing her as a "graceful", "kind" and "encouraging" mentor.
The work of famed British documentary photographer Martin Parr has been collected by some of the world's leading museums, including the Tate in the UK, the Centre Pompidou in Paris, and the Museum of Modern Art in New York.
He was known for capturing the reality of British life, and rose to prominence with his vibrant 1980s collection The Last Resort, showing people at the seaside town of New Brighton in Merseyside.
Among his other exhibitions was Only Human: Martin Parr, staged at the National Portrait Gallery in London in 2019, which captured the "social climate in the aftermath of the EU referendum" of June 2016. He also teamed up with photographer JJ Waller this year for Beside The Sea, featuring dozens of large-scale images of vibrant seaside life pasted on to the roofs of bus shelters in Brighton.
Parr, who died at the age of 73, was recognised with a CBE for services to photography in the Queen's 2021 birthday honours.
Another very British chronicler, writer Joanna Trollope died at the age of 82. She was one of the nation's most widely-read authors, penning more than 30 novels in a career that stretched back to the 1970s. She began writing historical romances under a pseudonym before hitting her stride with contemporary fiction.
She became known as the queen of the "aga-saga" (though it wasn't a term she much enjoyed) - detailing the lives and loves of characters in rural middle England. Her work tackled a range of topics from affairs, blended families and adoption, to parenting and marital breakdown.
In 1996 she was awarded an OBE for services to literature and was given a CBE in 2019.
The shocking murder of Hollywood director Rob Reiner and his wife dominated headlines in the middle of December. He and Michele Singer Reiner were found stabbed to death at their home in Los Angeles.
The director's son - Nick Reiner - was arrested and charged with the murders amid allegations he had been disruptive at a party hosted by Conan O'Brien the night before the attack.
Rob Reiner was the imagination behind some of the most iconic films of the last century, with credits including Stand By Me, When Harry Met Sally, The Princess Bride, A Few Good Men, and Misery.
But it was This Is Spinal Tap - which was followed up with a sequel in 2025 - that set him apart for British audiences. Using a fly-on-the-wall mockumentary style that was years ahead of its time, it told the misadventures of an English hard rock group on tour in 1984. The amp that turns up to 11 and climactic Stonehenge scene are the stuff of comedy legend.
An enthusiastic Democrat, Reiner's death had a bitter postscript. Hours after the news broke, Donald Trump took to Truth Social to trash him as "tortured and struggling, but once very talented", adding that he and his wife died "reportedly due to the anger he caused others through his massive, unyielding, and incurable affliction with a mind crippling disease known as TRUMP DERANGEMENT SYNDROME".
The circumstances of his death are sure to continue to provide headlines in 2026.
Singer Chris Rea, known for his festive hit Driving Home For Christmas, died three days before Christmas Day - after a short illness.
Rea found fame in the late 1970s and 1980s with hits such as Fool (If You Think It's Over), Let's Dance and The Road To Hell.
Known for his gravelly voice and latterly for his slide guitar playing, he was nominated for a slew of top awards, including Brit Awards, at the height of his success and sold millions of records.
News that French cinema icon Brigitte Bardot had died at age 91 followed just three days after Christmas.
Born in 1934, Bardot trained as a ballerina and worked as a model before turning to acting.
Her career saw her star in more than 40 films that transformed her into a global star and sex symbol of the 1960s.
She shot to international fame in the 1956 film And God Created Woman, which was written and directed by her then-husband Roger Vadim.
After retiring from the screen at 39, Bardot devoted her life to animal rights and founded the Brigitte Bardot Foundation.
